>>618469427
First, writing is confirmed to have been independently invented in only three places. These are China, Mesopotamia, and Mesoamerica. Europeans borrowed writing from Phoenicians of Lebanon, and Indians ultimately use a descendant of the Phoenician alphabet as well. The Japanese use a syllabary that was a variation on Chinese characters. And, just as you would expect, so did the Africans. The Swahili cities and the Sahelian kingdoms wrote in their own languages with the Arabic abjad, and Ethiopia invented its own alphabet, called Ge'ez, that ultimately originates from South Arabian scripts. How is African adoption of Middle Eastern or, later, European scripts any different from the European adoption of Phoenician? It may come as a surprise, but writing is hardly an intuitive invention.

The Nok culture of Nigeria, which emerged before the Greek city-states, were already smelting iron; already in 2004 UNESCO had recognized that this tradition was an indigenous innovation. Evidence has been found of ironworking in Niger as early as 1400 BC when no one in Europe knew how to smelt iron. This tradition of iron-working spread south with the Bantu expansion, and virtually all of Africa was smelting iron by 1500; even in Namibia, one of the most distant locations from the Bantu homeland.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The core gameplay of Death Stranding is walking.
There's a little bit of combat, but these moments are by far in the minority.
A walking simulator does not offer anything new to the human experience.
You can easily walk/hike in real life, for free.
Video games should allow us to experience what we can't in real life, be it unrealistic, economically unfeasible, or immoral.
Why is Kojima's walking simulator being praised as innovative?

Traversal in Death Stranding is brain-dead easy.
Balancing boils down to holding the triggers - literally kindergarten level.
But even the balancing aspect goes away once you get vehicles and exoskeletons, which is a massive shame.
There is no difficulty in navigation beyond simply not stepping over craggy rocks and deep water.
The amount of challenge is so elementary that it's laughable, serving absolutely no purpose other than to make your walk more frustrating.

The strand system is neither innovative nor implemented in a way that enhances the game.
Death Stranding did not pioneer the concept of indirect multiplayer cooperation.
The strand system turns "rebuilding America" into "trekking across America".
By linking up an area to the Chiral network, the player undeservingly inherits a rich array of infrastructure, robbing the satisfaction of building a network.
You no longer feel like you're rebuilding America.
Pioneers do get that satisfaction, but the strand system significantly hampers the ability of future players to enjoy the same process.
A game that implements "strand" gameplay properly is Dark Souls.
Players can offer assistance in the form of messages, which still allows the recipients to overcome the difficulty by themselves, thus not robbing them of any satisfaction.
Dark Souls doesn't force players to accept help from others. Summoning, is by choice.
Imagine if Dark Souls allowed other players to defeat a difficult boss in YOUR world without YOUR permission - that's what Death Stranding is.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The combat is boring, there is no challenge.
The only thing it does is slow you down, or separate you from your cargo.
BTs don't move, substantially reducing the suspense, rendering the threat almost comedic.
All the player needs to do is to walk around them. The only skill being tested is patience.
If caught, the player just needs to spam the shake-off button, which is just pinnacle gameplay right there.
With mini bosses, Sam can either escape at a slug's pace, or throw his piss, shit, and blood at the boss, over and over again.
There is no dodging, parrying, timing, spacing mechanics, nor any problem solving.
Just maintain distance and throw bodily discharge at the enemy until it's dead.
And guess what? The enemy HP doesn't even reset on player death!
The challenges presented to the player are just artificial and time-wasting.

The building mechanic is simply placing down a foundation, and tediously dragging materials to the foundation.
Once the road, bridge, or zipline is placed, the walking and the BTs can be skipped entirely.
Players who have built infrastructure won't elect to walk ever again, revealing the truth that the gameplay itself is boring.
Kojima drones who enjoy waiting for Sam to traverse over ziplines, and then listening to boring NPC monologue, over and over again, are deluding themselves.

The value of art is subjective.
But you can't just shit on a canvas and call it art.
The pretentiousness of Kojima is beyond insufferable and sets a terrible precedent for the video game industry.
The world of Death Stranding lacks variety.
Missions are Ubisoft tier copy and paste.
Buildings and rooms are identical.
Most of the story is delivered through journal entry exposition dumps.
The combat is repetitive.
All of this is a reflection of Kojima's low effort and creativity.
Celebrity cameos are not a substitute for gameplay, and won't be enough to save this dumpster fire of a "game".

Death Stranding sucks.
Kojima is a hack and a fraud.

As for fighting games, I also play some fightan, and I honestly don't have a problem enjoying PvE combat. Think of those really juicy combos you get once in a while that you can only get in very specific scenarios and require you to identify and execute in time that feel really fucking satisfying and treat the single player combat like a sequence of those. Now, not every game allows for this, but there are plenty of games that have reall satisfying combat that feels really nice to do the stylish combos or good sequences, and you can get some flow going. Maybe not particularly challenging, but challenge isn't always the main source of fun.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>618446820
>the only counterargument to SBMM is "I want to crush new players because I can't handle losing against fairly matched players"

It’s not the only argument. I’m not opposed to SBMM in every game, but for a casual game, it prohibits variety. It is fun to stomp noobs, it is fun to get stomped and have your ego get checked and feel the drive to improve, and it is fun to have an even matchup. If I had to only experience one type of game over and over in a game that I consider casual and don’t take too seriously, it makes the game predictable and boring.

That being said, I understand the main argument for SBMM is to help protect absolute beginners. I wouldn’t want to play against someone who doesn’t know where they Y button is either. So SBMM for the bottom 10-20% of players makes sense, but once you get out of the protected bracket, a range of 30-60% SBMM is ideal for the majority of the population.

"But I won!" says the tuna.
"So did your father," says the chef.

>>618466720
>What does this game do different than literally every other open world game that came before it?
How many open world games have you played in the past 15+ years?

Because I've player and/or seen just about every single one of them, and I can assure you that there has not been anything as non-patronizing, truly open-ended, and especially as interactive and dynamic as BotW, in ages.

It was truly exhilarating to NOT get cock-blocked by invisible walls or mission/story requirements and actually get to go anywhere I wanted to, even if it meant getting 1-shot by "OP" foes for hours to come.
It was amazing to be able to play the game for 80+ hours without doing a single story quest, and almost even beat the final boss before starting any plot-related stuff. And it was definitely fun to play around with the game's interactive physics and elemental systems, that allow crazy amount of creative, emergent gameplay.

And this is a late-2010s' Nintendo game. A title from THE company most known for its excessive handholding.
